The fallacy of relevance, also known as a red herring, occurs when the speaker attempts to divert attention from the primary argument by offering a point that does not suffice as counterpoint/supporting evidence (even if it is true). For example, if someone argues that we should focus more on national security and economic growth before addressing issues of respect for the dignity of all people, they are committing a fallacy of relevance. Similarly, if someone defends the government's actions by claiming that people are not capable of defending themselves or have no right to criticize, they are committing a fallacy of relevance.
